Award.AwardTitle: GOALI/Collaborative Research: Additive Manufacturing for a Highly Efficient Artificial Photosynthesis Device with Multi-Layer Interconnected Channels and Micro-Porous Structures

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to fabricate an artificial photosynthesis device that is capable of receiving and then converting sunlight, CO2 and water into sugars/glucose for the production of biofuels. Additive manufacturing (AM) enhanced by high-resolution heterogeneous material printing technology and multi-function nozzle array will be investigated to design and build the innovative device with multi-layer interconnected channels and micro-porous structures. In the channels, a water-insoluble hydrogel embedded with photosynthesis dark-reaction required compounds will be printed for CO2 fixation. On the top of the device, a layer of triblock polymer film will be created and function as the light reaction mesophyll layer similar to a real leaf. This research will enable manufacturing and deployment of large-scale solar conversion systems that not only mimic the natural process of photosynthesis for the production of biofuels, but also make these reactions independent of the life of nature plants.

If successful, the results of this research will lead to a new technology for designing and manufacturing an artificial photosynthesis device, which will help realize the vision of affordable bio-based energy manufacturing. Economically viable manufacturing of biofuels will greatly benefit the U.S. economy and energy security, as well as the society and environment in general. In the project, a long-term relationship with nScrypt, Inc. will be extended to encompass development and transfer of new technologies. Two doctoral students and up to six senior design teams will be trained. Three project-based learning modules will be created to strengthen the undergraduate engineering curricula in design, manufacturing and energy engineering. The project will also leverage specially designed outreach workshops for local high school and community college students, including many underrepresented minority students in Philadelphia, PA and Raleigh, NC areas, to showcase AM technology, photosynthesis process and green energy. The research finding and results will be disseminated through seminars, conferences, journal publications and various communication channels.

Institution.Name: Temple University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: TEMPLE UNIVERSITY-OF THE COMMONWEALTH SYSTEM OF HIGHER EDUCATION

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:     This is a collaborative research project involving three principal investigators, Dr. Jack Zhou at Drexel University, Dr. Wayne Yuan at North Carolina State University, and our component (Dr. Chong) at Temple University. The main objective of this research is to fabricate an artificial photosynthesis device that is capable of converting sunlight, carbon dioxide and water into sugars for the production of biofuels. Additive manufacturing (AM) enhanced by high-resolution heterogeneous material printing technology and multi-function nozzle array were investigated to design and build the innovative device with multi-layer interconnected channels and micro-porous structures. The specific objectives of our component (Dr. Chong) are (i) to optimize the function of the reconstituted membrane system to achieve a maximal light-to-energy conversion in the artificial photosynthesis system, (ii) to help evaluate the effectiveness of utilizing a porous polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) gas-liquid interface in the artificial photosynthesis device, and (iii) to implement undergraduate training related to this multidisciplinary research. One of our major contributions is the design, fabrication, and characterization of the free-standing archaeal tetraether planar lipid membranes over micropores in a PDMS-based microfluidic device. The membrane characteristics determined from electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) indicate that it is promising to use tetraether lipid planar membranes in micro-devices for various applications including artificial photosynthesis. In addition, the collaborative work with Drs. Yuan and Zhou demonstrated that porous PDMS is an efficient carbon dioxide-liquid interface for microfluidic applications. Carbon dioxide is required for artificial photosynthesis dark reactions. This grant led to two peer-reviewed publications and one manuscript being reviewed in the editorial office.

Broader Impact:     The obtained results have been published in ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces [(2014) 6, 12618-12628] and Appl. Biochem. Biotechnol. [(2015) DOI 10.1007/s12010-015-1731-y]. These results should be useful for future designs of more efficient artificial photosynthesis systems. The ability to generate stable archaeal tetraether planar membranes over micropores is likely to set a foundation for generating new planar membrane-based bio-technologies including the artificial photosynthesis systems. Artificial photosynthesis could have a significant impact on energy and economics. Four undergraduate students have been trained in this multidisciplinary project. They have gained experience in biochemical experiments and data analyses as well as in working in the interface between basic science and engineering.

 


Last Modified: 08/16/2016
Modified by: Parkson L Chong

These results should be useful for future designs of more efficient artificial photosynthesis systems. Artificial photosynthesis could have a significant impact on energy and economics. Four undergraduate students have been trained in this multidisciplinary project.
